Redescription . Measurements. Males: 4.4–5.9 mm , females: 4.5 –6.0 mm. Dorsal side glabrous, oval, convex. Body, legs and antennae completely metallic blue or bluish-black, except abdomen yellow (first ventrite sometimes infuscate along coxal cavities).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 11–16. Details of
Charaea mimicum
. 11—aedeagus (dorsal and lateral views); 12—spermatheca; 13—sternite VIII; 14—male last ventrite; 15—female pygidium; 16—female last ventrite. Scale bars: 0.5 mm for Figs 11 and 14–16, 0.25 mm for Figs 12–13.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Male (
Fig. 25
). Anterior part of head almost impunctate, along lateral margins of nasal keel covered with very fine punctures and fine short setae. Interantennal space 0.85 times as wide as transverse diameter of antennal socket. Interocular space 1.90 time as wide as transverse diameter of eye. Antennae filiform, 0.60–0.65 times as long as body, length ratio of antennomeres equals
11 - 6 - 6-12
-
11 - 11 - 11 - 11
- 11 - 11-15 .

Pronotum lustrous, 1.30 times as broad as long, strongly convex, widest in anterior third, covered with two kind of punctation: fine punctures on whole surface and large deeper punctures missing along lateral margin and in the middle of disc. Anterior margin straight, lateral margins slightly rounded, posterior margin widely rounded. Anterior margin very finely bordered laterally, in middle unbordered, lateral margins with broad border, posterior margin moderately bordered. Anterior angles obtusangulate, swollen, with setigerous pore in middle of swelling, posterior angles obtusangulate, with small pointed tip with setigerous pore, all pores bearing long pale seta, additional short setae visible on lateral margins of pronotum.
Elytra 1.45 times as long as wide and 0.75 times as long as body.

Length ratio of protarsomeres I, II, III and V equals
10 - 8 - 7-13
, of metatarsomeres I, II, III and V equals
12 - 7 - 6-12 .

Aedeagus symmetrical, subtubular, slightly wider anteriorly, ventroapically with wide triangular process, apex transversely cut, usually slightly concave (
Fig. 11
). Internal sac as in
Fig. 30
.

Distribution. Taiwan . Previous records of
Calomicrus coomani
from Taiwan ( KIMOTO 1966 , 1969 , 1986 , 1987 ,
1989 b
,
1991
) refer to to
Charaea mimicum
.

Biology. Part of the specimens were collected on the flowers of
Castanopsis formosana (Skan) Hayata
( Fagaceae ).

Differential diagnosis. In habitus,
Charaea mimicum
is extremely similar to
Ch. kelloggi
and identification based on external characters is difficult. Although males of
Ch. kelloggi
from the continent have black or bicolorous abdomina in comparison with completely yellow abdomina in
Ch. mimicum
, the Taiwanese population of
Ch. kelloggi
have also yellow abdomina, thus this character cannot be used. The males of
Ch. kelloggi
have slightly shorter incisions on the last ventrite ( Figs 8 , 14 ), females are indistinguishable. The main diagnostic features are found in the male genitalia. The aedeagus of
Ch. mimicum
is terminated by a longer ventroapical process with apex truncate, while that of
Ch. kelloggi
is shorter, and subtriangular ( Figs 5 , 11 ). Also the internal sac has a different structure in both species ( Figs 29, 30 ). The females of both species are almost indistinguishable.

Due to specific structure of the aedeagus and particularly the internal sac with long sharp lateral sclerites, both species belong to the
Ch. coomani
group. Besides these species the group contains
Ch. coomani
( Vietnam ) and
Ch. hainanicum (
Gressitt & Kimoto, 1963
)
(Hainan). However, a revision of this group is necessary because at least three additional species new to science from China , Laos and Thailand in the collection of the first author are awaiting description.
